title: 111_hr3774
content: The Energy Development Program Implementation Act of 2009 requires the United States to work with developing countries to find alternative energy solutions. The Federal Government is urged to implement title V of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act to reduce the risk of nuclear proliferation. In this Act, the term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "energy development program" refers to a program established under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Act. The term "Secretary" refers to a specific government official. The term "Secretary" in the Act refers to the Secretary of Energy, working with the Secretary of State and the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development. SEC. 4. ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION. The Secretary must develop strategic and implementation plans for the energy development program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. These plans must be submitted to congressional committees for review within the same timeframe, and implementation must follow within 180 days of the review. The Secretary must implement strategic and implementation plans for the energy development program within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Federal employees in the program will retain their benefits and be entitled to appropriations for fiscal years 2010 and beyond. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Secretary must annually report to congressional committees on the plans related to nuclear non-proliferation. Additionally, a report on the feasibility of expanding cooperative activities into an international effort must be submitted within a year of plan implementation. The report shall include an analysis and description of an Alternative Energy Corps to encourage technically trained volunteers to work in developing countries on energy projects using non-nuclear resources and renewable technologies, as well as other mechanisms for coordinating international efforts in energy development. The report aims to promote the use of appropriate technologies in developing countries.
